Without reading 1,482 comments preceding this one, it's worth pointing out that when we use the term "hurricane", it always describes tropical cyclone events that occur in the Atlantic Ocean and Northeastern Pacific Ocean. These weather phenomena feature counterclockwise rotation due to Coriolis forces. So, your graphics featuring clockwise rotation more correctly describe tropical cyclones in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans and typhoons occurring in the Northwestern Pacific Ocean. A rather interesting aspect of your side-by-side counterclockwise-clockwise cyclone depiction VERY nicely matches the overturning circulation that occurs within a single cyclone, regardless of the hemisphere. Air inflows at low levels at the surface and, due to convection, rises near the centre of the vortex at the eye wall. Subsequently, you see the outflow at the high levels near the tropopause as the air mass cools. The overturning aspect sees the cooler air falling earthward at the outside, thereby causing the close--proximity opposite rotations. Instead of it being two cyclones side-by-side, however, it's a SINGLE cyclone as viewed as a cross-section. If you look straight down at a cyclone, it's effectively a vortex ring with a few additional interesting features, such as feeder bands.

I'm a meteorology student at university, so when you talked about hurricanes and how they related to these vortex rings, that was cool. The first example you showed of the hurricanes, when they are both in the same hemisphere, and therefore spin the same way is called the fujiwara effect. When this happens to hurricanes, they usually both get weaker, though the stronger and larger storm is usually less affected by this interaction. The other one that you mentioned with hurricanes when they are spinning in different directions happens fairly often in the Indian Ocean when one hemisphere's hurricane season is winding down, and the other one is starting back up.

You wanted a prediction^^ here we go:

I think the vortex cannon with a square hole has more trouble producing a stable vortex. See, the rings are spinning at every point equally fast when produced through a round hole, but when you use a square as outlet of the cannon, I think it is difficult to get a stable vortex, because the corners have more flowing material, which results in a pressure difference inside of the ring. Normally the round shape forms equal forces to cancel each other out very symmetric, but a square is a more complicated form, which could lead to instable vortexes. You can't say that every part of the ring is pushing every other part forward. That would violate Newton's 3rd law. The way it works is that the outside of the ring throws air backwards, whereas the inside throws air forward. Because there is an imbalance between inside and outside the ring, there is a resulting forward force. As the ring becomes smaller, there is less air for the inside of the ring to throw forward so the resulting forward force increases.

I'd like to see what happens for shapes with different side lenghts.  For the even sided shapes, it follows that the respective corners would advance, and the delay between corners (the length of the sides) would impact their shape in the third dimension as they propagate (the rectangle).  It follows then that a trapezoid, or other more irregular 4-gon would see even more irregular forward propagation as a function of the time taken for the respective corner superpositions to happen.  I suspect some aspect of this would make the vortex ring steerable.

At 4:52, an intuitive reason that the Hurricanes orbit is that the velocity at the center must cancel out by symmetry (assuming they are the same size). You can sort of see this in your graphic, but also since it is not from a full CFD simulation, it's not going to be perfectly accurate. This means that if two hurricanes get closer together, they will orbit faster because the velocity is higher closer to the center. In the case of the vortex ring, since the directions are going the same, the inside velocity is faster, making the vortices move faster. Edit: I said this before you got to this point in the video.

I predict it'll become a circle - because a circle is the lowest-energy configuration for this system. Those sharp corners of the square use up more perimeter for the amount of air that's rotating, and thus is less "efficient." Nature abhors high-energy states, so the ring will snap back to a circle. It's the same reason that a square bubble wand still produces spherical bubbles.

EDIT: Alright, seems I was mostly right - it becomes a circle. I'm surprised about the oscillations, though - I'd expect them to die down much faster than they did. And the "forward and backwards" wobbling was a right shocker.

Other interesting questions we didn't have time to explore in the video, but if you like reading here you go:
- Why a ring going around a ball breaks apart. Every single time we tried, the ball would interfere with the ring, even if the ring was clearly much larger than the ball, as in 2:14. We kind of thought the vortex ring would expand over the ball, but finally realized that vortex ring is spinning so that the air on the inside of the ring is moving forward, so it drags against surface of the ball. Sad.
- The leap-frogging rings at 2:17 were surprisingly hard to make because small currents in the air tend to send the vortices off an a different path. The reason they leap-frog around each other is the same reason hurricanes spin around each other as shown at 4:52.
- We shot a smoke ring at a 1-inch pipe, a rope and a thin wire. The pipe killed the vortex. The wire passed right through the vortex with no effect. The rope sometimes killed the vortex ring, sometimes not, depending on how strong the ring was. We wanted to quantify this interference, but alas, I have to start working on a video about black holes. Get pumped.

Thanks for watching, y'all! I love making these videos, especially when I get to play around with the science for a while and cool people join me.

My hypothesis for the square hole is that the vortex will still be a torus. I think that because knowing a vortex is created by air on the sides of an initial air movement spin back and then are fed back into the main center current creating a ring, because knowing that the circular hole is circular for the most homogeneous flow of air, the square means that the corners will output higher speeds of air and the edges will output slower currents of air. Because of that, the air current will quickly form itself into a cylindrical flow creating a torus-like vortex but slightly weaker.
Edit after seeing the answer: It probably doesn't stabilize into a cylindrical flow and instead goes into a circle but the inertia of the current will bring the shape of the flow further into a square/diamond and then it collapses back towards a circle again.
